header.title: Outcry over claims people over the age of 75 ‘shouldn’t get the vote’
header.postText: Jamelia has provoked anger after suggesting that people over the age of 75 shouldn’t have a vote.', 'In the wake of the Brexit chaos, the singer said those who won’t be around to see the consequences of their ballot should not have a say.', 'Her words were met with widespread condemnation, including fellow Remainers who said democracy should be open to all.', 'Speaking on the Jeremy Vine show to a pensioner, named only as Pat, Jamelia began by telling the caller not to get offended.', 'She then added: ‘I think that you’re completely capable of being of sound mind. I think you are capable of making a vote.', '‘I just don’t think it’s fair that you have a vote when you’re not going to experience the consequences of that vote.', '‘And you’ve had 50-60 years old voting.’', 'Pat was less than impressed and replied: ‘Why can I not, with my own conscience, vote for what I believe in?’', 'After the show, viewers and Twitter uses rounded on Jamelia, pointing out that being young was no guarantee of surviving to see the consequences of the vote.', 'They said people who have worked and paid taxes should continue to have a say while many politicians voting in Westminster were over this arbitrary age limit.', 'PMason74 said: ‘People of 75 have lived through various types of governments and a few recessions. Why not stop under 21s or people that have never worked or students that have never paid tax?’', 'Spectrumsarebeautiful added: ‘Jamelia’s view seems to be “if you don’t agree with what I think, you should lose your vote.’', 'Poppet said: ‘This segment left me feeling cold and slightly nauseous. To speak of elders as second class citizens and state “don’t be offended” your opinion doesn’t count anymore is discriminatory.’', 'While Alan S added: ‘So, youthful ignorance beats the wisdom of age and experience? You think people with limited life left are thinking about themselves and not their families who will be living on. You are at the very best, delusional.’', 'Rebecca Green said: ‘So, with that theory, should anyone with a terminal or prolonged illness be denied the vote Jamelia even if they are in their 20s?’', 'Official figures for the Brexit vote put the number of Leave votes at 17,410,742 – 51.89%. This is compared to 16,141,241 to stay – 48.11%.', 'However, there was a clear generational split and – if Jamelia’s ban on older voters was ever implemented – it could well have been a different result.', 'The under 25s were twice as likely to vote Remain (71%) compared to the over 65s (36%).', 'The 25-49 year old group narrowly voted Remain (54%) compared to 40% of the 50-64 year old category.', 'By the time the UK leaves the EU on March 29, there will be another 2,000,000 more young people eligible to vote.', 'Based on the demographic change, the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE) recently estimated a 52%-48% vote for Remain in 2021 and 54%-46% by 2026.', 'However, even anti-Brexit youth pressure group Our Future, Our Choice disagreed with Jamelia.', 'Co-founder Lara Spirit told Metro.co.uk: ‘We’re strong believers in democracy. We think everyone should have a vote, including over 75s.', '‘While there is a generational divide, particularly on Brexit, it’s not the case that anyone’s vote or voice should matter less than anyone else’s.’
header.socioLingVar: Age - General,Age - Over 65s,Ethnicity - General,Age - Youngsters, Ideological and Political Identity - General,Gender - General,Nationality - European or anti-Europeans,Social Class - Working class

commentThread.commentText: What a sadly misinformed suggestion to make. Many young people are knowledgeable and thoughtful about their choices, but many are less so, just as in all age groups. All young people lack the experience of age. We do not suggest barring thei r age group due to lack of experience, nor should we. Just as we should not suggest barring over 75 year olds who do have significant life experience, from voting. What next? You have to demonstrate that you will live a minimum of 10 more years to be able to vote? After all, life expectancy of a 75 ye ar old in the UK is a further 12 years. What next? You have to prove that you have resided in the Uk for X amount of years and will continue to do so, in order to prove that you will be impacted by the political choice? I wonder when our younger generation lost their respect for their fellow citizens? Shame on you yo ung woman.

Jamelia does not know that it was young people who in the 1975 referendum voted to stay in Europe. Over 40 years later, those same 'young people' now older, voted for Brexit.The gave the EU a good go, but after 40 years decided it wasn't for them.

replies.commentText: They also now know, what they were told in 1975 was a very big lie. The people were told the EEC was and would only ever be about trade. Yet if you read the government papers that have recently been released, the whole idea was for a United States of Europe from the begining. Makes the little red >bus look irrelevant.

commentThread.commentText: It`s brainless morons like this who should be barred from voting.
I don't know what the voting situation is like in GB but, I don't think anyone under the age of 25 should be allowed to vote in the U.S.A.Primarily because so many squander that right to begin with.

This foolish young woman reckons that people over 75 should lose the right to vote. Perhaps she should remember that it was those people who campaigned against the bomb, sat around the perimeter of Greenham common, marched for peace, fought in wars and gave her the opportunity to live in a World where she can voice her misguided views. In fact, without our generation and my elders, Jamelia would find herself without the protection of anti discrimination laws, after all, it was my peers who fought for rights for women, salary parity, rights for all races and rights for her generation. This is a youn g woman whose brother is a murderer, perhaps she would be well advised to campaign for the rights of victims of crime, instead of patronising and insulting thousands of decent older people. Or is it just a publicity stunt?
I agree, however Jamelia is too nice.  You should lose the ability to vote once you're 60.

One might even be moved to seek to raise a commitee to discuss this possibility in a serious tone, whilst genuflecting to your purported youthful expertise and understanding of the nuances of political decision making.

Plenty of people over 75 still work, or pay taxes on pensions.3. Students, those who have always been on benefits do not pay taxes, but get a vote?4. Anyone can die, while more and more love well beyond 75.Crawl back under your bridge, or maybe do something more interesting to claw back your fame.
How would she feel if somebody said only people with strong British DNA should be allowed to vote?

Ok - but if we are going to discriminate like this - perhaps nobody that hasn't LIVED in this country for at least 18 years should be entitled to vote - after all they have done little if anything to CONTRIBUTE to this country - so why should they have any say in it?The two arguments seems to have equal merit. One discriminates against people who have contributed all their life - one discriminates against those who have contributed little or nothing.Bet I can guess which one the PC brigade claim is "free speech" and which one is xenophobic/racist etc etc.On a different tack, perhaps the votin g age should be raised to at least 25 - so that there is at least a remote chance that young people have had to time to forget the biased indoctrination from their teachers and tutors - and have at least had a chance to learn the BASICS of politics.
So does this rule apply equally to all those with terminal illness, or those who are likely to die young, the suicidal and the mentally ill?. Or is it pure unadulterated ageism.
